newsitem.title: FRANCE: ALPINE SKIING-KNAUSS TAKES WORLD CUP LEAD WITH SUPER-G WIN.
newsitem.headline: ALPINE SKIING-KNAUSS TAKES WORLD CUP LEAD WITH SUPER-G WIN.

text.p: All-rounder Hans Knauss led Austria to another triumph in Val d'Isere on Monday, winning a men's Alpine skiing super-G one day after compatriot Fritz Strobl took the first downhill of the season.
Knauss, who takes the World Cup overall lead away from Norway's Kjetil-Andre Aamodt, beat compatriot Guenther Mader by 0.03 seconds with a time of 1:23.26.
Only Swiss Steve Locher stood in the way of a second Austrian clean sweep of the podium in two days.

Locher, winner of the first giant slalom of the season in Solden last month, took third place in 1:23.43. But Austria still had four men in the top five with downhill world champion Patrick Ortlieb, third on Sunday, missing the super-G podium by 0.26 seconds. Christian Mayer was fifth on 1:23.78.
"You had to be a very good technical skier to win here," said Knauss, who won his first super-G last year in nearby Valoire.
"My main goal this season is to win the super-G World Cup. The rest will be a bonus," added the 25-year-old from Schladming.
But he has shown that he may be capable of doing much better, finishing fourth, third and second in the three giant slaloms held so far this winter.
The results put him firmly in the World Cup overall lead on 297 points, ahead of Aamodt on 234 and Locher, who has 215.
Knauss, who also won a giant slalom in Alta Badia last season, said a nose operation in the spring had solved the breathing problems which had sometimes hampered his performance in the past.
Mader's second place came as a relief for the veteran all-rounder, who had a disastrous downhill on Sunday, finishing 50th.
Locher, another giant slalom specialist, also confirmed his fine early form.
The three men on the podium will be among the favourites in next Sunday's giant slalom in Alta Badia, which should see Italian superstar Alberto Tomba in action.

The Alta Badia race may also see Norway's Lasse Kjus, the World Cup overall winner last season, return from a week at home to recover from sinusitis. Kjus will miss a slalom in Madonna di Campiglio on Tuesday and two downhills in Val Gardena later this week.

The super-G was held in warm and sunny weather, contrasting with the appalling conditions which had forced a women's giant slalom to be called off and a men's downhill to be delayed by 24 hours in the French resort.
Local hero Luc Alphand, sixth in Sunday's downhill, was eighth in the super-G, 0.72 seconds behind Knauss, but he had a reason to celebrate.
"I'm very happy Locher pipped Ortlieb for third place. It would have been a very bad weekend for me if Ortlieb had twice finished on the podium", said the downhill World Cup holder.
The Frenchman and the Austrian have started a war of words this season and their duel, which resumes in Val Gardena, should be one of the highlights of the season.
